title: 109_hr2328
content: The Act may be cited as the "Children's Access to Vision Act of 2005". Congress finds that good vision is crucial for children's physical and educational development. Early detection of ocular conditions is key for effective treatment and can have long-term benefits for vision health. Identification methods like vision screening programs or comprehensive eye exams can help identify children in need of services. Children identified through these methods should receive appropriate treatment. Children identified as needing services should have access to subsequent treatment as needed. SEC. 3. GRANTS REGARDING COMPREHENSIVE EYE EXAMINATIONS FOR CHILDREN. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants to States for comprehensive eye examinations for children, prioritizing those under 9 years old. This includes treatment for vision problems and educational materials on recognizing signs of visual impairment in children. The Secretary will develop criteria for the grant program and data collection related to vision assessment. Coordination with other health programs is required. The Secretary will develop criteria for a grant program for children's vision screening, requiring an application with specific information and a plan for fund use to complement existing State efforts. Funds will be used as a secondary payer to State compensation programs. The grant program for children's vision screening will provide funds as a secondary payer to State compensation programs and entities offering prepaid health services. States receiving the grant must submit evaluations of vision service utilization and children's status annually. The grant program for children's vision screening allows funds to be used for the collection, analysis, and reporting of vision data as per guidelines set by the Secretary. The grant can also be used for other information required by the Secretary. Grants can be used for purposes other than comprehensive eye examinations without penalty, and there is a limitation on grant expenditures. The grant program for children's vision screening allows funds to be used for comprehensive eye examinations, with a limitation on grant expenditures. Definitions for comprehensive eye examinations are provided, and there is an authorization of appropriations for funding.
